title: QSR General Manager Judgment Assessment (Advanced)
description: High-fidelity situational judgment and operational decision-making assessment for QSR General Managers using nuanced, weighted scoring.

questions.content: Lunch rush is peaking. Two crew members call out, DT is backing up, and you are short a key position. What is the BEST action in the next few minutes?

options.text: Step into the most constrained station yourself while directing the shift lead to rebalance the rest of the floor
Quickly reset the rush plan: reassign positions, narrow focus to core items, and align the team on DT pacing
Temporarily slow order flow by tightening handoff checks while the team stabilizes
Hold current assignments steady to avoid confusion and reassess after the rush peak

questions.content: DT times have gradually increased over the last 15 minutes. What response is MOST likely to sustainably improve throughput?

options.text: Reinforce urgency at the window and encourage faster handoff
Shift your strongest communicator to expo and clarify ownership of drinks, bagging, and runner roles
Pre-build popular items slightly ahead to absorb spikes
Accept slightly longer DT times to preserve order accuracy

questions.content: A top performer is consistently fast but is skipping a handwashing step during rush. What is the BEST immediate response?

options.text: Correct the behavior briefly and keep them in position to avoid disrupting flow
Pull them aside, reinforce the standard, and reassign if needed to protect food safety
Note it mentally and address it in a post-shift coaching conversation
Assign another team member to double-check their work until the rush ends

questions.content: You notice temperature checks were missed on a batch prepared during peak. What is the BEST course of action?

options.text: Immediately verify temps and discard only what cannot be validated
Re-check temperatures now and document after the rush
Discard the batch to eliminate risk and keep moving
Flag it for the next shift to review when volume slows

questions.content: Morale is slipping during peak. You sense frustration and short tempers. What is the MOST effective quick intervention?

options.text: Briefly acknowledge the pressure, restate one clear goal, and reinforce teamwork expectations
Focus solely on execution and address morale after the rush
Rotate one stressed team member to a lower-intensity task
Let the shift lead handle morale while you focus on numbers

questions.content: Sales are tracking 20% below forecast at 2pm. Labor is currently at 33%. What is the BEST decision in the next 30 minutes?

options.text: Reduce one non-critical position now and reassess in 30 minutes
Re-forecast the afternoon, start breaks early, and protect peak-critical stations
Hold staffing steady until sales stabilize to avoid service gaps
Make a larger cut immediately to get labor back in line

questions.content: Your labor target is 28%. You are trending at 31% with four hours remaining. What is the BEST next move?

options.text: Stagger early outs for lower-impact roles while maintaining coverage for expected peaks
Delay any cuts until you see actual sales results
Trim hours evenly across the team to spread impact
Make a decisive cut now to get ahead of the number

questions.content: A case costs $48 and yields 24 servings. What is the cost per serving?
A team member has opened late twice this week. What is the MOST effective response?

options.text: Document the issue, coach expectations, and align on a prevention plan
Issue a formal warning to set a clear tone
Adjust their schedule to reduce risk of recurrence
Monitor closely for another incident before acting

questions.content: A high-performing team member asks for flexibility on a minor policy because they deliver results. What is the BEST response?

options.text: Reinforce that standards apply consistently while acknowledging their contributions
Allow limited flexibility short-term while coaching expectations
Redirect the conversation to performance goals and avoid policy discussion
Escalate immediately to formal discipline to set precedent

questions.content: ROLE PLAY (3 minutes): Coach a late opener. Address impact, expectations, and next steps while maintaining engagement.
ROLE PLAY (3 minutes): Handle a guest upset about DT speed while keeping throughput and tone steady.
ROLE PLAY (3 minutes): Correct a food safety lapse during rush without escalating team stress.
Values & Compliance: Describe a time you intentionally slowed operations to protect standards. What tradeoffs did you consider and what was the outcome?
